5177648/5176465/5201216.title: Lucht Siúil
5177648/5176465/5201216.text: The tramps that used to travel the village of Coonagh were Sweet Vale of Avoca, Thomas Barrett, Law Loughlin and Matty Kane.Sweet Vale of Avoca used to go around the village every Monday and go from house to house singing the "Meeting of the Waters". He used to get a penny or twopence in every house. When the people of the house would not have a penny to give him they would take him in and give him a cup of tea.Tom Barrett used to come round on a Sunday. He used only go to the farm-house when the dinner would be over and he would get the leavings. He used to drive round in an ass and cart and when he would be going home he used to get a "beart" of hay for his ass from each farmerMatty Lane and Law Loughlin used to drive around in an ass and cart both of them selling oranges.

5177648/5176466/5201218.title: Lucht Siúil
5177648/5176466/5201218.text: The beggars that come to Meelick are Gray Mary and Old Barrett.When Gray Mary comes she carries a bag She has it full of potatoes and parsnips She sells on her way to make money. She also carries an old can and a flute. The can is sometimes full of milk. When she comes to the house she plays the flute She gets a penny or maybe a cup of tea. She sits at the side of the road to smoke her pipe. She is very cross to children when she meets them. Mary is very black.When Barrett comes he brings an ass and cart and goes from farmer to farmer for a "sop" for his ass. He also gets a penny.It is seldom you see beggars in cars.

5162141/5158043/5201420.title: Lucht Siúil
5162141/5158043/5201420.text:
The names of the tinkers that come to our house are the Carthys the Caseys the Burkes and the Doyles. They come to the school very often. When they come they ask for money and when the teacher gives it to them they would want another thing, and when they get it they say "God bless you" or "the Lord have mercy on the Souls that have left you. There is a very wicked woman and she is called "Big Bridge" because she is very big and she has a big fat face and she always has a black eye and marks because she is always fighting. Her real name is Casey. There is another man with a hair lep and he is called Sean Balb because he is not able to talk properly. His real name is Carthy.The tinkers always have a cart and a "barth" of straw in the middle of the cart and the women sitting on it. The cart has very high wheels. They usually
(continues on next page)

5162141/5158044/5201421.title: Lucht Siúil
5162141/5158044/5201421.text:
(continued from previous page)
stop at a cross road or boreen and they set up a tent there. They put a fire down with little sticks.The tinkers that were long ago are Billy Furey and he was very wicked another was Terry O Brien he used to be mending pots and ovens.



There are always some beggars in the Country. The usual names of the beggars that come to our house are the Cartys, and the Caseys and the Doyles. They always asks food and clothes and money and when they get anything they say "God bless you".Big - Bridge is also a well known tinker  She always has a black eye because she gets drunk and she fights with the other tinkers and she is in jail oftenThe why she is called that name is, because she is very big. Her real name is Casey
(continues on next page)

5177649/5176673/5202143.title: Lucht Siúil - John Ahearne
5177649/5176673/5202143.text:
About 60 years or so ago, John Ahearne, the Knight of the Teapot, visited this place regularly, about once a year.He travelled in on ass and cart & carried his own bed & bedding. He put up in houses in the district. He might spend 3 or 4 nights in one district, but never stopped the 2nd night in the same house.Some gentleman got the cart made for him & gave ass & harness. The cart was painted slate-colour & the painter painted a teapot & the inscription "Knight of the Teapot" in white
(continues on next page)

5177649/5176674/5202144.title: Lucht Siúil - John Ahearne
5177649/5176674/5202144.text:
(continued from previous page)
lead on cart, as a joke.He never carried goods for sale. He took alms (a copper generally, and did not care for potatoes). He never gathered rags &c.The people always were glad to see him & he got the best place near the fire. He made his bed in the kitchen.His cart was so constructed that he could raise a sort of pent-house from back under which he went in rain



Tom Hickey, a simpleton, from Co. Limerick. He visited this place up to about 50 yrs. ago. He travelled on foot & wore no boots. He'd take
(continues on next page)

5177649/5176675/5202145.title: Lucht Siúil - Tom Hickey
5177649/5176675/5202145.text:
(continued from previous page)
any alms he'd get. Potatoes were a common alms for him He always carried  them in a bag supported in front of him on his outstretched arm; 5 stones of potatoes were no trouble to him.About a night was as much as he wd. spend in one house. He was always more than welcome.His simplicity is still proverbial. If a person does anything very foolish, we hear "Tom Hickey w'dn't do that."He used to wear a policeman's coat & trousers.



Mick Bourke (Potato-Fye), from Cahernorry in Co. Limerick. He reigned

5177649/5176677/5202146.text:

Frost's & Martin Ryan's of Lower Meelick.Tom then began to teach Mick his prayers. Mick wanted no praying and replied with curses.They slept in the same bed in which they were separated by a board to keep them from fighting.



Jack Curley, over 60 years ago, not over wise, used to wear a policeman's jacket, used to arrive about dark to put up for the night. Never carried a bag. Used to get coppers.

4811619/4802618/5202551.title: Tramps
4811619/4802618/5202551.text: There was a man there long ago and his name was Andy Gorman. He used to sleep in a van near the main road.This man used to make chairs and tables. He used to go around to the houses selling them.Lots of people around this district bought them and they have them always. This man was very well liked by the people.He used to stay around this district for a month.

4811619/4802619/5202553.title: Tramps
4811619/4802619/5202553.text:
There was an old tramp there long ago whose name was John Releighan. He had a big high hat and whiskers almost down to his stomach. He came from Millstreet. When he was going around here he had a bag about six feet long. This bag used be full of old coloured papers. Every man and woman he'd see he would offer them a smoke of an old pipe he had. One day he went into a shop in Rossmacowen. He asked for a halfpenny worth of each of the following:- tea, sugar, and tobacco. Then he got a big pot and filled it with water. He boiled the water and threw the sugar and tea into it. Everybody that passed he called them and asked them to drink some of his fine tea.
(continues on next page)

4811619/4802621/5202556.title: Tramps
4811619/4802621/5202556.text: Long ago there was  a man going around here by the name of  Jerry Corkery. He was from Allihies. He used to come around here and stay in some house for a couple of nights and  he used to go away to some other place then. He was very good for telling stories, and for singing songs.His favourite song was The State of Arkensaw. He was found dead in Ardgroom a couple of years ago.

4811619/4802622/5202557.title: Tramps
4811619/4802622/5202557.text: There was a man travelling allong the road long ago. He was called Johnnie Walker. He had only one hand and was once in the army. He was born in Galway. He had a lot of stories and he used to stay in Johnnie Spencer's house. He used to do a little work for people in the summer if they would pay him.

4811619/4802623/5202559.title: Tramps
4811619/4802623/5202559.text: There was a woman there long ago by the name of Mrs Good. She used go from house to house taking charity and when she used get the charity she used say the Lords prayer and God spare the health. God spare the sight. She used stay in a farmers house for a night or two and every night she used sayHeart of Jesus I adoreHeart of Mary I imploreHeart of Joseph pure and just in these three Hearts I place my trust.

5177651/5176960/5202579.title: Old Travellers
5177651/5176960/5202579.text:
449            Old travellers.Long ago poor people had a very hard way of living.                    One time a priest was walking a road and he got so tired that he went into a woman named Mrs.Barry and he asked her for lodgings and she said she would.But when her husband came in he would not let anybody stay inside his door and the priest said he would sleep on the chair by the fire and would feed himself .The husband said he would not allow him and the priest went away and he said "long life to you mam "but a very short life to him .So after a few weeks the husband
(continues on next page)

5202625/5158148/5202687.title: Pedlars and Tramps
5202625/5158148/5202687.text:
Tramps call to houses in this locality at the present time, but there are very few of them now. In the old days when there were work houses in Ennis, Corofin, Ennistymon, Kilrush, and Kildysart tramps were almost a pest this locality, because the village of Ruan was the only village between Ennis & Corofin, and they used make it a halting ground between the two places. These tramps used travel all over Ireland. They very rarely had anything to sell but went from house to house asking for a "Copper". What were known as "Beggars used also come round this locality, and those asked not for coppers but for potatoes or a plate of meal, and they had bags in which they carried those away. Some of them used come to this locality every six months, others might not come except once every two or three years. There was another class who used carry many cards of pins and needles - large & small - and they used give a few of those in exchange for old rags - woollen rags being most in demand - this was a form of "Barter". Sometimes they used have very cheap cups and saucers which they used give in exchange for empty bottles. There used be
(continues on next page)

4798667/4788564/5202754.title: Travelling Folk
4798667/4788564/5202754.text:
Travelling Folk 7-6-'38Nearly every day throughout the year we see some travelling Folk.  They are always poor people that you see travelling.  Nearly every one of those has some occupation.  The men sweep chimneys or put a bottom in a kettle or a can that might be leaking.  The women sell little things such as saucepans which they make themselves and lanterns which they make themselves also.  Some of them are more familiar to us than others.  The following are well known the McGinleys or the McDonaghs.  There was a Mrs. Gray and her son in this place.  When she came she would stay more than a week and go from house to house.  If there were any meetings or patterns about the country.  A man named John Sampey from High Bog used to go to them and he would be the first man to be seen there.  Then there was such a man as Jimmy Moore who used to go about from house to house telling stories to the people.  Everybody liked this man.  Young people followed him to what ever house in which he would be telling the story.  He used to take nights for one story.  He begged a little too.  He had a box for the tea, and a box for the sugar.
(continues on next page)

4811620/4802786/5202957.title: Travelling People
4811620/4802786/5202957.text:
The following are the the names of a few travelling people who visited locality some years ago. It was a pleasure to see some of them coming because some of them used to tell stories. Some of them never told a story.Jim Coffey and his wife. Pat Purcell and his wife who had a donkey and car and they spent one winter in this wood.John Collins came from Cork City he was a soldier in the great war and when it was over he came back
(continues on next page)

5162142/5158296/5203055.title: Lucht Siúil
5162142/5158296/5203055.text: A good many beggars and travelling folk come to our house now and again. Not always the same ones come. Well, let me commence with Jimmy Casey. He gathers "spuds" and the next one that comes is his brother Peter.He sells little things such as stockings, pins, and studs. Mary Breen and her comrade, Kate Scully, always come together. Mary Bully Nevin and lots of other tinkers, Carthys and Scullys call. All these are from Kilrush. We often buy little things from them. They get all these things in Kilrush. The people have great welcome for them.

5162142/5158297/5203056.title: Ráthanna agus Liosanna
5162142/5158297/5203056.text: There is no lios in the school district. The nearest lios to us is in Doonbeg. It is shaped like a hill and flat in the centre. It is in Considine's farm in the townland of Rhynagonaught. It is called a fort. There is a grazing field around it. There is a hole in the centre. People go in around it. Nothing ever happened them. There was no one of them (the forts) ever destroyed. The people say that it is not lucky to have anything to do with forts.

4798668/4788771/5215540.title: Travelling Folk
4798668/4788771/5215540.text:
The travelling folk of nowadays differ very little from the travelling folk of olden times.  They have the custom of going around from house to house begging for alms.  They travel from place to place in caravans.  These people are not at all poor.  Some of them sell small articles namely, pens, brushes, cans, jugs and sauce pans.Usually the travelling folk are not welcomed in our homes  If the people chance to see them coming, the door is at once closed.  They are not admitted into the house.As a general rule they sleep in tents on the road sides or in the lanes.They carry no food with them at all.  They depend on the food they obtain in each house.  The alms they usually obtain are flour, bacon, tea, sugar, eggs, etc.  Some of the travelling folk go around on bicycles.  The best known among the travelling folk or tinkers who visit our district are Stokes,
(continues on next page)

4798668/4788772/5215541.title: Travelling Folk
4798668/4788772/5215541.text:
(continued from previous page)

Long ago there were numbers of poor people travelling the countryside. Some had no means of living except what they begged or got by charity from the country people. Others made scanty living by the sale of small articles. These poor people had no home of their own. They got a night's lodgings in every house. Their bed consisted of straw.



The travelling folk of nowadays are called tinkers and gypsies. Most of them go about in caravans. Some of them sell cheap jewelry, straw mats, linoleum, pictures, flowers and lace. the men tinkers sell saucepans, cans, and other articles made of tin. The best known of  the tinkers are Stokes, Reilly's, McDonaghs, and McMands. Poor people often ask for a night's lodging in country houses.   Sometimes they are allowed to stay for two or more nights.  They usually sell such articles as pictures, beads, vases, medals and artificial flowers.  Long ago such people used to stay in certain houses in each district for many nights at a time.  They used to beg during the day and obtain lodging in the country houses at night.  People bought their wares, and gave them free lodging.



The usual Travelling Folk of the present day are the Tinkers. They usually travel in bands, or caravans. The principal Tinker tribes in this district are the Cawleys, Stokes, Reillys, Wards, MacMonds and MacDonaghs. The menfolk work at the tinsmith trade, making various articles of Tinware, such as cans, saucepans, lanterns, colanders, basins, etc.  The women folk carry these articles around from house to house, and try to sell them to the house-holders. These women go in pairs, and harass the country folk. 5162134/5157140/5215870.text:
473          Travelling people.There are many grades of travelling people there.Two grades which is intimately known  around this locality are the working kind and the begging kind.These are seen every day going from house to house and begging.        The travelling people that come to my house are the Caseys ,Mc Carthys and the Burks.            The Caseys are natives of Kilrush and they come to this locality selling camphor balls  and pins and many other different articles.           The Mc Carthys are natives of Kildysart .They go from house to house selling brushes ,tins ,and buckets.The men make these themselves from tin.            The Burkes are natives of Mayo.He mends all sorts of articles such as :-Pots ,buckets ,kettles and umbrellas.If these are badly broken he takes them to where
(continues on next page)

5162134/5157142/5215873.title: Travelling People
5162134/5157142/5215873.text: The travelling people are seen almost every day going from house to house. The travelling people that come to my house are the McCarthy's, Burke's and Caseys.The McCarthy's are natives of Kildysart. They go from house to house selling brushes, tins, and buckets. The men make these themselves and the women sell them. The Burkes are natives of Mayo. The men men all sorts of articles such as buckets, pots, kettles, and umbrellas. If these are badly broken they take them to where they have their camp. The Casey's are natives of Kirush and they come to this locality selling pins, and camphor balls. Gypsies are seldom seen in this locality. They tell the people their fortune. The sell lace, cloth, pins and holy pictures. Travelling people are very healthy because they are out in the open air every day and every night.

4921760/4904262/5217930.title: Tramps and Beggars
4921760/4904262/5217930.text:
1. Siobhán a'Cléibh was an old woman who carried a cock around with her. She would not let any feather grow on the cock. When any tiny feather was appearing in his skin she used to say "Fé mar cuirfeadsá tríot é bainfead-sa díot é." She took the cock to Mass with her, while Mass was going on she stood outside the Church door shaking holy water on the cock. When he began to crow she used to say "Bí Glaodhac".2 Seán na mbreach.    He used to go into the river and say "Sh Sh" and all the trout would gather around him. He used to catch them and through them out on the bank. Meanwhile other people would come along after him, and take away the fish unknown to him.3. Seán na gCat.   He used to carry a bag of cats around with him.(These, 1,2,3 from Mrs Twomey Inches)4. Colonel OSullivan   was a travelling man who was descended from OSullivan Beare. He visited
(continues on next page)

5162135/5157250/5218482.title: Tramps
5162135/5157250/5218482.text:
Tramps call to the houses in this district from time to time. It is the same people that generally come.The names of the tramps that come to this district are the Carthy's, Casey's, and the Burke's. The local ones come from Kilrush. They have small articles for sale, such as studs, camphor, brushes, and small pictures Some of them sell articles made of tin such as sauspans, buckets, and tincans.They are usually all bought from them or they often leave them to the people that give them charity. They get the goods in the town they come from. The people have not much welcome for them, but long ago the people had great welcome for them.They stay a night or two. The sleep on the
(continues on next page)

5215796/5211588/5219278.title: Travelling Folk
5215796/5211588/5219278.text:
There are many people travelling through Ireland. They are known as tinkers and gypsies. The tinkers have a very hard time because they are always hungary. They keep moving about from place to place.The women beg for food such as, flour, milk, tea, and sugar. The men beg for hay
(continues on next page)

5215796/5211632/5219289.title: Travelling Folk
5215796/5211632/5219289.text:
There are a great deal of people travelling all over the country called tinkers and gypsies. The gypsies travell in caravans drawn by two horses. The tinkers have carts and they live in tents along the roads.They are always poor and they have nothing to eat. They beg food from the people
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208051/5219428.title: Lucht Siúil
5215779/5208051/5219428.text:
Not many of those travellers came to this place now-a-days but long ago they were very plentiful.  The people new all those people that went around.  One woman used to come around and the people we knew her well.  Her name was Mary Stocky.  She always carried a basket with her and had it filled with lovely things.  She used to sell blessed-pictures and pins and a lot of useful things the the people wanted.
(continues on next page)

5215796/5211653/5219527.title: Travelling Folk
5215796/5211653/5219527.text:
There is a great deal of tinkers travelling round now. The go from house to house asking cherity. The more the get the more they want. The have horses pulling the tent  Before morning the horse might be dead. The will go to the tinkers for the horse again and the fire bottles
(continues on next page)

5215796/5211693/5219605.title: Travelling Folk
5215796/5211693/5219605.text:
A great many people travel the country called tinkers. They sleep in tents and caravans.They are a very healthy class of people. The men make saucepans and cans, and the women makes flowers. They sell these things and they make their living on that. They are almost all the time
(continues on next page)

5215796/5211722/5219625.title: Travelling Folk
5215796/5211722/5219625.text:
There are a great deal of travelling folk in Ireland. They travel from one place to another in vans and carts and they beg their food from house to house as they go along. The men beg for hay to feed the  horses and the women for flour and milk. Those people are
(continues on next page)

5215796/5211743/5219640.title: Travelling Folk
5215796/5211743/5219640.text:
Tinkers and gipseys travell the road from place to place. Some of them sleep in vans, and others sleep in tents. They never do  any work on the farm. They make cans and sauspans, and they sell them to the country people, and they get a lot of money for them. If they get an
(continues on next page)

5215796/5211770/5219655.title: Travelling Folk
5215796/5211770/5219655.text:
Thousands of people are going around Ireland. These are known as tinkers and gypsies.Some of them are very useful. The men make cans and saucepans and they also fixes pots.The women make flower and they also sell carpets and stools. They go from place to place and some of them
(continues on next page)

5215796/5211793/5219671.title: Travelling Folk
5215796/5211793/5219671.text:
There are many travelling folks in Ireland such as tinkers and jipsies. The tinkers have caravans and they go from place to place. The women go through the country begging flour, tea, and sugar. The men beg hay for the horses. They fix  saucepans, cans and pots. They gather sticks for the fire. The tinkers have
(continues on next page)

5215796/5211847/5219893.title: Travelling Folk
5215796/5211847/5219893.text:
There are many travelling folk in Ireland. They go from place to place in small caravans. They go through the country begging for food and money. They get plenty of food to eat. Some of them make cans and
(continues on next page)

5215614/5206548/5219910.title: Lucht Siúil
5215614/5206548/5219910.text:
Tagann fear beag an slíghe seo go moon minic bíonn sé ag díol go leor rudaí beaga mar snathaidí, bioráin, snáth, cíor. Bíonn a cuid tae féin aige agus déanann sé é i dteach eicínt. Bíonn sé ag cur síos, ag cainnt ar an tír agus an chaoi a bhfuil na barraí tríd an tír.Fadó bhí bean ag siubhal timcheall an duthaigh seo. Bíodh sí cos-nochtaighthe i gcómhnuidhe, leigeadh sí uirthi féin go raibh sí bacach acht nuair a bhí sí in áit uaigneach béadh sí indon siubhail cómh maith le duine ar bith eile. Sé an deire a béadh sí ag iarraidh ná olna agus tugadh "Slaimín Olna" uirthi ach tá sí ar slighe ná fírinne anois.Timcheall cúig bliadhain ó shoin bhíodh fear siubhail ag taisteal an áit seo. Aodh Mac Eoin a tugtar air. Ní fhágadh sé an baile ar
(continues on next page)

5215796/5211884/5219933.title: Travelling Folk
5215796/5211884/5219933.text:
The tinkers and gypsies travel through this country begging for a living.  Some of them  live in a house on wheels, and it is drawn by horses. Others live in tents made from oilcloths.The women beg for flour, tea, and sugar, and they sell saucepans. The men beg for hay and straw, and they
(continues on next page)

5215796/5211903/5219952.title: Travelling Folk
5215796/5211903/5219952.text:
Tinkers travel the country from place to place. They sleep in tents and houses on wheels. They are a very healthy class of people. They rear large families. The women made flowers and sell them. The men make sauspons and cans. They buy nothing what so ever
(continues on next page)

5215796/5211929/5219970.title: Travelling Folk
5215796/5211929/5219970.text:
Long ago there lived in the village of Graffy an old man and an old woman. One day a tin-smith came into the house and he asked a charity in the honour of God. The old man showed him the door, but still he continued to ask. At last the old woman told the
(continues on next page)

5215796/5211962/5220007.title: Travelling Folk
5215796/5211962/5220007.text:
These people go through Ireland looking for a living. They are known for many years as tinkers. They have their tents along the road. They make their tents with big oilcloths.The men buy tins and they make cans. The men sell the tins, and in this way they buy food.
(continues on next page)

5215796/5211996/5220174.title: Travelling Folk
5215796/5211996/5220174.text:
There are a great deal of travelling folk in Ireland. Some of them are called tinkers and others are called gypies. Some of are them sell cans and others sell flowers and lace. The men buy horses mules and asses. The women beg food, and the men beg hay, and oats for the horses. the
(continues on next page)

5215796/5212022/5220187.title: Travelling Folk
5215796/5212022/5220187.text:
There are hundreds of tinkers and gypsies going around the country from one place to another. Some of them beg for a living. The men make sauspans and cans and they fix leaking buckets. The women make flowers from coloured paper. The
(continues on next page)

5215788/5210820/5220252.title: Beggars
5215788/5210820/5220252.text: 1.Thirty or forty years ago, beggar were more plentiful than they are now. They went from house to house asking for alms. Nobody refused them for a "charity" or a nights lodging, because Our Lady and Saint Joseph were refused for a lodging on the first Christmas Night. Teh beggars came periodically. Tom the Thrasher (because his father used to thresh long ago) was one of them.

5215788/5210848/5220316.title: Special Days
5215788/5210848/5220316.text:
(continued from previous page)
If you sow Oates on the day of a full moon you will have bad oats.Trí lá na Risbhoige. The three first days of April. These days are so called because long ago March with its cold severe weather had nearly killed an old cow and when she was not dead on the 31st of March she borrowed three days of April to kill her.  Ever since the three first days of April are very cold.



Forty years ago beggars were more plentiful that nowadays. They went from house to house asking for almost nobody refused them for a nights lodging becaus Our Lady was refused lodgings on the first Christmas Night. They came periodically Tom the Thresher was one of them.

5215779/5208128/5220750.title: Lucht Siúil
5215779/5208128/5220750.text:
In this district poor people go about from house to house begging food & old clothes. There names are Doran's. & Sweeney's. The women carry baskets with them. In the baskets they carry pictures & statues, brooches & collar-studs. They buy them themselves in the wholesale shops in town. They sell them to the country people. When they come into a house they stay for about a quarter of an hour. They ask alms, such as old shirts & trousar's, & old
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208211/5221033.title: Lucht Siúil
5215779/5208211/5221033.text:
There was man who was going around this district. He used to be selling all kinds of things. He had no house of his home and he slept in a barn or a carthouse. He was often hungry and cold and he used to come into the houses and they used to give him a piece of bread. He carried a bag on his back and he used to sell all kinds of things. He used to sell statues and brooches and collar-studs and all other things. Sometimes he used to be falling down with
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208333/5221395.title: Lucht Siúil
5215779/5208333/5221395.text:
About 20 years ago there was a family of people called Collins. They waited only about three or four days. They used to have a lovely painted caravan in which they used to carry their goods and sleep at night. The man used to go round from place to place selling statues and brooches and collars and studs and a lot of other little articles. They
(continues on next page)

5215813/5214724/5221528.title: Tinkers
5215813/5214724/5221528.text: The Tinkers also visit this district sometimes, They travel on donkeys and in carts, in families. They camp on the  roadside. During the day they go around to the houses. The men ask for bottles, rags, and horsehair, and they give needles and pins in return for these. The women ask for eggs, flour, old clothes and other things. They sell holy pictures, paper flowers and other things. They sell cans and saucepans also.

4921777/4906282/5221609.title: Travelling Folk
4921777/4906282/5221609.text:
Mrs O'Brien of Kanturk is a well known member of the present day travelling folk. She resides in Kanturk and travels around the surrounding district daily in a horse and car. She is commonly known as the "Were King's" wife, as he husband collects tin boxes and makes candle holders, muzzles and flower barrels. These she sells, on her daily travels, for a few pence each. She collects bottls and jam pots.The Coffey Family - The Coffeys also visit our district. They have a caravan drawn by a pony and a donkey. Their usual stopping place in this neighbourhood is at the Ball Alley, Coolbroeimore, Banteer. From there they visit the houses in the surrounding district selling soap, laces, studs, pins and holy pictures. As payment for these articles they are satisfied to accept eggs, sugar or tea. They usually pay monthly visits to this locality.Mrs. McCarthy, another well known character comes here occasionally from Kanturk. She specialises in fortune telling - cutting cards or reading palms. She is about twenty years of age and is tidily dressed. If she is not paid in each for her services she
(continues on next page)

4921777/4906283/5221612.title: Travelling Folk
4921777/4906283/5221612.text:
(continued from previous page)
asks for food.About 45 years ago Denis O'Connor, a shoemaker used pay visit to Banteer. He was known as "The Warrior" and was a great angler. Sometimes he used make boots for a whole family at one time and used live in the house with her family whilst he was making the boots. At the end of a day's fishing he used cook "the catch" at Con Duggan's Banteer, who was the local smith at that time. "The Warrior" sometimes had to sleep in the barns of the local farmers. He was very superstitious and used be very annoyed if he happened to meet a "foxy" woman especially if he were setting out on a journey.



Daniel O'Connell, a native of Killarney, Co. Kerry travels through the country districts seeking alms. He sells on his journeys laces, studs and other small articles. He sleeps in the outhouses and haybarns of the country.Barefoot Charlie: About forty years ago, a
(continues on next page)

4921777/4906285/5221618.title: Travelling Folk
4921777/4906285/5221618.text:
(continued from previous page)
with a stick. He generally put up for the night in old disused houses and children used be terrified of him. Just the same he was very honest but wild and hot tempered in drink. He got plenty to eat on his travels.Stephen Kirby - Another travelling man who used to visit the Banteer district many years ago was Stephen Kirby. Kirby was a native of Derry and was a very tall, well-built man. He was dismissed from the R.I.C. because he was too fond of drink. He lived principally in the Macroom district but was very fond of visiting Nadd Banteer. He used visit the R.I.C. Barracks and get assistance from the police. He tramped through most of Cork Kerry and died in poverty.



Bill the Ram - One of the most famous of the travelling folk of the old days was known as "Bill the Ram". This strange name was given to him because he had a pet ram that used to follow him around like a dog.Full of my Arms - Another old travelling man was known as "full of my Arms" This name was given to him because on entering a house he had a habit of putting his arms around the first person he met and
(continues on next page)

4921777/4906286/5221622.title: Travelling Folk
4921777/4906286/5221622.text:
(continued from previous page)
saying "the full of my arms in every bit of you".Mary the Dogs. A famous travelling "lady" of the present day is known as "Mary the Dogs". She was born in Donoughmore, Co. Cork and owned a good farm of the land but sad to say she got into very poor circumstances and had to sell out her land to pay her debts. After some time she was reduced to such poverty that she was forced to beg from door to door.One night during the Irish war she got lodgings in a house and during the night soldiers raided the place. She got such a shock that she almost lost her reason and has continued very strange in her manner ever since.She dresses in bags - one for a skirt and one for a cape. She loves cats and dogs and is never seen without a dog on a lead. One time her dog died and she used to carry his dead body around with her in a sack. After this she got the name "Mary the Dogs."



Jack Dudley used frequent this district collecting bottles and rabbit skins and he used give in exchange needles, pins and brooches.
(continues on next page)

5235084/5233697/5235176.title: Beggars
5235084/5233697/5235176.text: There were plenty of beggars in the olden days before people thought of relief but the kind hearted feeling people of those times never referred in my district to them as beggars they were poor men and poor women.Those poor people always came in modestly with a God save all here, never asked anything but the good women of those days understood and the help was given unostentatiously just like sister to sister, or brother to brother, those giving thankful to God to be able to give and saying or thinking it would never be missed.  A lot of charity was done that the world never knew, before the people became as mercenary as some of them are today.  Cans of buttermilk and a pat or two of butter smuggled in, flour to make a cake, visiting a poor sick neighbour and taking some dainties that they might not have.  Those good turns seldom passed unrewarded because if the children or when they became properous in other lands some of them never forgot their good kind neighbours.  Pity this spirit of helping each other would ever be allowed to die out.

5235093/5235014/5235373.title: Travelling Folk
5235093/5235014/5235373.text:
Travelling folk still visit our locality but less frequently than in former times. Those who survived the cold winters back, still come but the majority of them are dead. Some of these sell small articles such as studs, tiepins, picture-frames laces, needles, camphor and several other little things. They obtain their supplies in Cork at some cheap firm, generally at Woolworths. People buy from them as an act of charity.    They are welcome whenever they visit the locality, and are given food and lodging while they remain which is generally only one night. They sleep on the settle, or long seat usually found in farmer's houses. People fill bags of chaff after the threshing to have for the travelling folk to sleep on, and special bed-clothes are set aside for them. Any of these
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208418/5235570.title: Lucht Siúil
5215779/5208418/5235570.text:
There are very few travelers going about here at present. The Dohertys and the Dorans came last year but they did not stay long. They sell all kinds of fancy delph (?) and little statues and broaches and collar studs and carpets. They get all their goods in the big wholesale shops in town. They never ask for lodging because they sleep in big vans at night. Long ago, there was an
(continues on next page)

5235087/5233972/5235684.title: Old Story
5235087/5233972/5235684.text:
(continued from previous page)
a priest a man a woman and two policemen having a convict with them.  He stopped his horse and he saw them erect a gallows and hang the man.  He saw the priest administer the last sacraments.  The man said, why isn't Tom Flangan at mass and the woman whom he knew died ten years before said "what do you care if Tom Flanagan never went to mass".  The people then vanished and the man went his way.



Travelling people do not now call to the houses but used to do so long ago.  They used to be doing that for several years.  They were not very poor. They used to sell small articles camphor, needles, pins and basket made from moss.  People used to buy the articles from them and they used to get their supplies from hawkers and itinerant dealers.  They were always welcome and seldom remained for longer than a night.  They slept in the
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208576/5235893.title: Lucht Siúil
5215779/5208576/5235893.text:
In this district People go about from house to house begging food. and old clothes. Their names are Dorans Maughans and Sweeney's. The women carry a baskets with them. In the baskets the keep blessed pictures the sell them to the people in the country. The buy them in the wholesale shops in town When Doran he came to this village first the people did not know
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208679/5235966.title: Lucht Siúil
5215779/5208679/5235966.text:
Not many travelling people come about out place. I think they are the same people that come every time, They were of one family and their names were Gallaghers. They were a very nice family and any time they came into a house they stayed about two hours. There was a man amongst them and he was very fond of telling stories. Many story the old people have after this man. One day this man came into some house and told a story about three men who went out to earn their living and when they
(continues on next page)

5235091/5234704/5236346.title: Travelling People
5235091/5234704/5236346.text:
Travelling People.*Paddy Leary from the west of Kerry used come to Listowel long ago. He used go around begging and used describe all the story about the lakes of Killarney. They used call him Holy Paddy because he was very holy. There was another man from Ballylongford whom they called "Mick the Bottles" because he used go around gathering bottles. He used lodge at a house in Tay Lane, Listowel."Pats do buide" from Ballybunion. His pockets were always full and his jaws were always moving. He was always chewing somethingDaniel Heffernan suffered from imagination and he thought he was over the landlords. He used go around to the farmers advising them not to pay the landlords that he would get a reduction He used always have a bundle of papers in his pockets and every Saturday he would go to the court to get a reduction for a person. These
(continues on next page)

5235091/5234708/5236348.title: Travelling People
5235091/5234708/5236348.text:
(continued from previous page)
and he would go after them like a mad bull waving his blackthorn stick at them all the time.



There was an old man and nobody around would let him stay in their house and then every night when any door would open he would make a gush and lep the door and into the Bed.Bob Stack was an old travelling man and he used go round the country sleeping in the peoples houses and he often slept in Ned King's house in Astee.There was an old man and his name was Paddy the Gom and he used go around the country reading stories for the people and every person around used come in and listen to him reading from a book that he had. 5215813/5214858/5237437.title: Travellers
5215813/5214858/5237437.text:
No people travel in my district except a woman called Sara Follan. She comes in July or August. She asks for wool, tea, sugar and pepper of the people. She asks tobacco for [?] also. She sells the wool in the town and gets money for it. She travels on foot and she geos [?] in her feet most of the year. When she came first she spoke all Irish but now she speaks bits of broken English. She brings news some time. Sometimes a band of tinkers comes. They camp on the roadside. They travel in carts, on
(continues on next page)

5215813/5214994/5237820.title: Travelling Folk
5215813/5214994/5237820.text:
No people come around my district now except an old woman named Sare Folan. The most time of the year she comes in June and July when the people are sheering the sheep. She does begg for eggs and wool and potatoes.First when she used to come she used to speak all Irish but now she speaks English and Irish. She used to stay in a house named McLoughlin.There was a old man going around named Billy Cudden. They
(continues on next page)

5236104/5232923/5237863.title: Local Travellers
5236104/5232923/5237863.text:
Travellers are not so plentiful in this place as in other places. The name of the poor man that is going round this place is Tom Hussey. He is about seventy years of age. He has a stoop in his back.He carries a stick in his hand because he has a lame step. He  goes from house to house and he gets a penny or two pence at every house in that place. There are others going round also but
(continues on next page)

5008903/4965472/5237958.title: Travelling Folk
5008903/4965472/5237958.text:
Although there may be a great number of rich people in Ireland, there is also a great number of poor people to be found in our district as well as in any other.The same families have been travelling as long as I can remember and I don't think they are as poor as they pretend.The Donovan and Connor families visit our house more frequently than other travelling folk.Eileen and Jim are the heads of the Donovan family. They own a caravan, and three horses, two donkeys, and two trucks. There are two compartments in the caravan :- a bedroom and a kitchen, and if you don't mind, they have a gramaphone, and then they will tell you they can't get a bit to eat.In the day time they go about with a basket selling needles, thread, laces, holy pictures, and I could not tell you how many other little things.
(continues on next page)

5008903/4965475/5237960.title: Travelling Folk
5008903/4965475/5237960.text:
There come an old man and woman to our house about once a month. They go by the name of the Hands.They have a donkey and cart, a couple of dogs and a goat. I expect they keep the goat to keep themselves and the dogs in milk. The dogs keep them in food by catching rabbits.They generally put up their tent at Davidstown, for they like to be convenient to the pub, as they take a wee drop. They come home a bit merry, and some-times the revel finishes in a boxing match.Another crowd that call at our house, go by the name of the Donovans. They don't come very often, but when they do come they stay around for days, and you would not get a minute's peace with them as they are always looking for something, bread, meat, sugar, tea, potatoes, and God knows what else.They go around with baskets
(continues on next page)

5215813/5215338/5239252.title: Travellers
5215813/5215338/5239252.text:
There are no travellers seen in my district, now except a woman named Sara Fallon. She is very poor. She sells no articles but she begs for alms. She goes around to every house and they give her wool, money, eggs, tea, and other things. She comes about three times in the year. Wool she begs for offenest. She sells the wool in Westport. When she came around first she spoke all Irish. She speaks broken English now. Sometimes she brings news to the people. When she comes to a house she makes
(continues on next page)

5215813/5215428/5239633.title: Travelling People
5215813/5215428/5239633.text:
Travelling people still call to our houses. Some of them have being doing so for many years. They get alms from the people such as woll, eggs, tea, sugar and potatoes. They go to the town and sell the wool and eggs. They stay in some houses for a week. They do have food with them sometimes. Some travel from place to place on foot. Some of them do have a donkey for carrying their load.29/4/38 been,The names of the best known
(continues on next page)

5236102/5231852/5239902.title: Travelling Folk
5236102/5231852/5239902.text: Many tinkers visit our district, they usually come in families. The principal tribes of them are, the O Briens, the Cartys and the Donoghoes. When they come around here they usually stay at the end of the foothpath at Greenville or at Coolnaleen cross.They come around a few days before the big fairs, the races, Easter and at Christmas. They depend on the flour, meal, potatoes and milk that they get at different houses to support themselves. They make flowers of coloured paper which they sell, they also sell holy pictures, combs, brooches and candlesticks.They buy tin and make saucepans and gallons out of it. They make their own caravans which they live in.

5236102/5231923/5240029.title: Travelling Folk
5236102/5231923/5240029.text: Many tinkers visit our district. They usually come around before the races and before big fairs. They stay at the end of the footpath in Greenville or at a cross-road.There are different tribes of them there:- The O Briens, the Carthys and the Donoghues. They usually travel around in caravans. They often go round from house to house begging for food to feed themselves. They get flour, milk, potatoes.They also go round selling holy pictures, brooches, combs, and flowers made from coloured paper. They also buy tin and they make gallons and saucepans out of it. They go round and sell them to the people.

5236102/5232004/5240161.title: Travelling Folk
5236102/5232004/5240161.text:
Travelling folk is another name for the tinkers and they visit our house very often. They take small articles with them and the people buy them. They ask alms in every house and the alms they ask are:- a few eggs, a couple of potatoes or a grain of flour. The names of the different tribes of tinkers are:- the O'Brians the Carthys and the Donovans and they usually put up at the end of the foot path in Greenville or at Coolnaleen Cross.They come round at big fair days and at Christmas and also at the races. They buy the tin and make the articles. They make sauspans, pannies, tin cans and gallons
(continues on next page)

They sell pins, brushes and boot laces. They buy them in the towns. They have a big bag on their back. The people have great welcome for them when they came to their houses. They stay that

Generally before a big horse fair they arrive. They all gather near the town. They come around for big fairs and Races. They trade on tin cans and on making tables. They change sixpence. They make saucepans and other things. They stop at certain places on the road. They stop over at the forge gate in Greenville. They tell you your fortune in the palm of your hand. 5236102/5232188/5241860.title: Travelling Folk
5236102/5232188/5241860.text: There are many tribes of travelling people around my district especially tinkers. At certain times of the year the travelling people come around this district especially before big fairs and the races. There are certain places in my district where the travellers stay. At Ballyhorgan Cross and Blackpool Cross. The best known are the McCarthys and the O'Briens. The tinkers come around a few days before a big fair and they go around to every house asking alms such as eggs and money. In my district the tinkers stay for three day and during that time they go around selling tables and other small articles. Long ago it was the Gypsies trade to make tables but now the tinkers make them also. Another trade by the tinkers is making of tins. The tinkers go in bands made up of sometimes a couple of families.

5236102/5232230/5242006.title: Travelling Folk
5236102/5232230/5242006.text: There are several kinds of travellers going around namely Charles O Brien, Patrick Doherty, Michael Coffy, James Mac Carthy. Generally before a big horse fair they all gather near the town. Some of them put up at Coolnal Crossand at Listowel bridge. Some of them are very poor. They go around to the houses begging and gathering food. They get meal, bread milk. They make small articles such as tables and they buy the tin and make saucepans, gallons, quarts and go around from house to house selling them. In the winter they travel in wagons but in the summer they take the covering off the wagons and travel in open cars.

5236102/5232283/5242228.title: Travelling Folk
5236102/5232283/5242228.text: Travelling folk still visit our district. The Travellers that visit our district are the O Briens and the Mac Carthys, the Coffeys, the Flins. Some of these travellers make gallons and other tin articles and tables and sell them. Most of these travellers have vans and they go from place to place. More of them go on foot and carry a velvet cloth with them to make a tent where they want to stop. Before a big fair they always come around our district.

5236102/5232414/5242552.text: There are many kinds of travelling people in the district. Certain times of the year the travelling people come around a few days before big fairs and stay at Coolnaleen Cross. The tinkers go in bands, made up sometimes of a couple of families. In my district the tinkers stay for three days and during that time they go around selling tables and other small articles.

5236102/5232468/5242600.title: Travelling Folk
5236102/5232468/5242600.text: The tinkers usually visit our district and they nearly always come in families. There are different sections of tinkers, the OBrians, the Carthys and the Donaghues. They usually come before the races or a big fair-day. Some of them sell candlesticks, holy pictures, brooches, combs and other things. They make flowers themselves of paper and sell them also. They also beg for flour, meal and other things that support life. They travel in cars from place to place and they sometimes stay on the side of the roads near some shady place and remain there for a couple of days.

Travellers call to our house very often now. Their names are O'Briens. They have been travelling around for many years. These people are very poor. They sell many small
(continues on next page)

5260407/5249753/5262002.title: Travelling Folk
5260407/5249753/5262002.text:
Travelling people still visit my house. The same people that usually visit our house at intervals, some of them are poor. They usually sell small articles and people buy from them. Some Travellers stay a week in a place and others only stay a few days. They sleep in their cars. They buy their food and cook it themselves. They take milk, sugar and other things.
(continues on next page)

5260407/5249852/5262056.title: Fairy Forts
5260407/5249852/5262056.text:
(continued from previous page)
surrounded surrounded



Travellers visit my house very often. The most common people that come are the O Briens and the Mc Carthys. They sell small articles they make themselves. People buy these articles from them. Some of these expect to get eggs and flour. These people
(continues on next page)

5260407/5249907/5262087.title: Travelling People
5260407/5249907/5262087.text:
Travelling people still call to this district but they are not as numerous as they were long ago. These travellers are poor and cannot pay for lodgings and therefore they depend on the people for lodgings. Some of them sell small things such as, laces, fongs, safety pins, ballads and other things. All people buy from them. They are generally welcome because they bring much news with them
(continues on next page)

5260484/5258457/5265957.title: Lucht Siúil
5260484/5258457/5265957.text:
Since I first remember tramps have been coming to my house.  We know them all because they come from this locality.  The families that visit us most frequently are the McCrorys, the Dohertys and the O Rourkes.  In addition to these other wandering individuals come.  These come from time to time in caravans and have no fixed place for themselves.  They are the Friels, the Joyces and the McGowans.  They have no ballog of their own and
(continues on next page)
5260484/5258457/5265957.school_info: School: Sgoil Naoimh Conaill, Na Gleanntaí

5260484/5258477/5265974.title: Lucht Siúil
5260484/5258477/5265974.text:
Since I first remember tramps they have been coming from time to time to my house.  Most of these tramps come from the back streets of Ardara.  They do not pass the road without visiting you.  It is the same tribe who always come, but occassionally strangers appear sometimes.  Very few day[s] ellapse that I do not meet some of the following tribes, such as the O'Rourkes, the Boyles, The Dohertys, the Friels and the Magrorys.In addition to those tribes, there are other individuals
(continues on next page)
5260484/5258477/5265974.school_info: School: Sgoil Naoimh Conaill, Na Gleanntaí

5260484/5258556/5266126.title: Lucht Siúil
5260484/5258556/5266126.text:
Since I first remember there came a tramp to my house from time to time. Most of these came from the parish of Ardara. Some of these tramps come looking for alms, but most of them have cans or something to sell. Some of the names of the tramps who come to my locality are, the O'Rourkes, the Boyles, and the Freels. Sometimes these tramps come looking for lodging  but it is very seldom that they get this.The tramps of long ago came mostly looking for lodging and if they would not get this they would curse the house. Therefore the people were afraid of these tramps, and the latter usually got what they wanted. One night
(continues on next page)
5260484/5258556/5266126.school_info: School: Sgoil Naoimh Conaill, Na Gleanntaí

5260484/5258576/5266134.title: Lucht Siúil
5260484/5258576/5266134.text:
In the locality that I live in, it is customary for tramps to visit it, and remain in it for a few weeks. Some of them are, the O'Boyle's, O'Rourke's, Freel's, the Joyses, and the McKeon's and many others. The most of them come from Ardara. Some of them come's and remains in the houses, and indeed there is no great welcome for them in the locality.Some of them come with donkeys, and horses for sale, and the peculiar thing about them is that they never
(continues on next page)
5260484/5258576/5266134.school_info: School: Sgoil Naoimh Conaill, Na Gleanntaí

5260484/5258595/5266283.title: Lucht Siúil
5260484/5258595/5266283.text:
We have local tramps around this place by the names of Boyles, Doherties, & McGroary's. They come from Ardara. and some times they camp outside. They come round selling mats, rugs and tins. The tramps are welcomed sometimes but if they stay around for a long period, and be drunk they are not. They buy their own food and sometimes they ask for alms. The people give them pennies, old bottles, and clothes. Nearly all those tramps have hounds and some of
(continues on next page)
5260484/5258595/5266283.school_info: School: Sgoil Naoimh Conaill, Na Gleanntaí

5260484/5258624/5266306.title: Lucht Siúil
5260484/5258624/5266306.text:
The tramps that occassionally visit our house are they O'Rrourks, the Dohertees, the Boyles and othes that come very seldom about once each year. Most of these tramps come from Ardara and always travel on foot because their journey is short. The others that come from far away come on vans and carts but they carry with them their camps to stay here for a while.Those tramps from this locality do not take food for themselves but depend on the other people to give them alms. These people give alms such as bread, eggs, flower, and meal and oft times give them coppers. These (traps) tramps give tins, lace, brushes, and other articles which they
(continues on next page)
5260484/5258624/5266306.school_info: School: Sgoil Naoimh Conaill, Na Gleanntaí

5260484/5258834/5267371.title: Lucht Siúil
5260484/5258834/5267371.text: Since I first remember Tramps have being coming to my house. I know them all they O'Rorkes, The Boyle's, the Dortherty and many others (thing) families. There are many other Tramps who comes from time to time. Some of them has things for sale such as mats, camfer, pencles, laces, flowers, pictures, clothes, soap, and many other things. The people buy some of these things. Some of the people do not welcome them. Some of these reads fortunes for a sixpence.
5260484/5258834/5267371.school_info: School: Sgoil Naoimh Conaill, Na Gleanntaí

5260484/5258880/5267418.title: Lucht Siúil
5260484/5258880/5267418.text:
Since I first remember tramps have been coming to our house. They mostly all come from the Ardara district. There are the Boyles the O'Rourkes the Dohertys and many others. When they come to the house they do not ask for lodgings but they come with things to sell. They sell suits, trousers, shirts, dresses, mats, tins, mops, pictures, combs, glasses and campher. The people buy these things and then the tramp praises
(continues on next page)
5260484/5258880/5267418.school_info: School: Sgoil Naoimh Conaill, Na Gleanntaí

5260484/5258893/5267429.title: Lucht Siúil
5260484/5258893/5267429.text:
In my locality now, tramps are not as plentiful as long ago. Nearly all the tramps now-a-day's come from Ardara. The O'Rorke's, O'Boyle's, McGroary's and many others to my home often. Sometimes they are selling little things such as mats, pencils, or cloth. When they are selling something useful there is a welcome before them.Long ago there lived a number of tramps in Letterilly called McGarvey's. In Letterilly there are not a great number of houses and they would
(continues on next page)
5260484/5258893/5267429.school_info: School: Sgoil Naoimh Conaill, Na Gleanntaí

5260484/5259015/5267639.title: Lucht Siúil
5260484/5259015/5267639.text:
As long as I remember there always came tramps to our house sometime in the day. There are a number of tramps from the locality who usually visit our house but sometime during the year there comes strange tramps to my locality. The local ones are the Freel's, the O'Rourke's, the O'Boyle's, the O'Doherty's and the McGroary's. Some of these have caravans and other have donkeys and carts. The ones with caravans and vans sleep in them but the tramps with carts
(continues on next page)
5260484/5259015/5267639.school_info: School: Sgoil Naoimh Conaill, Na Gleanntaí

5260463/5254347/5268913.title: Games
5260463/5254347/5268913.text:
(continued from previous page)
and one would be in and they would hit the ball and run around the ring and if they were hit with the ball the would be out. The way to play hides is one party would blind and the others would go in hide and the ones that would be blinding would catch the rest.



Tinkers very often come to this parish. They have asses and carts and some of them have caravans. The go around to the
(continues on next page)

5260463/5254375/5268949.title: Games
5260463/5254375/5268949.text:
(continued from previous page)
and rounders. We play hide and seek by having one or two blinding and others hiding and the ones who blind must hatch the others. They also play football.



During the years of the famine 1847 and 1848. All the crops failed and were burned except the wheat and oats and the peoplel had to sell them to pay the rent. The old people tell us that when the people dug the potatoes and gather them, the poor people came and dug the ground again to get all the potatoes that escaped.



There are four families of travelling people in this parish.
(continues on next page)

5260463/5254701/5274390.title: Lucht Siúil
5260463/5254701/5274390.text:
There do tinkers camp in my district. They go around from house to house begging tea, sugar, flour, bread, and clothes. There do tinkers called Doyles, Caseys, and Donovans. The Donovans camp near my house. They make buckets and tin cans, and they also mend things. They have a pony and car, and a few asses. The Doyles do not camp around here. They deal in asses and horses, and they are well all. The Caseys camp near my house, they make buckets and they also put hoops on buckets for people in the district. There are tinkers called McCarthy's that camp in my district
(continues on next page)

5260463/5254760/5274477.title: Wild Animals
5260463/5254760/5274477.text:
(continued from previous page)
hear anyone coming they run into the den. The foes have many borrows near my house.The rabbits are also very helpful around here they have meadows and fields destroyed, they have all the grass eaten off them. The people set snares for them and they also shoot them. The badgers are not so plentiful, but there are some of them around here.



There do a great many tinkers pass this way. They go into every house and they ask everything such as, flour, sugar, tea, milk and bread. It is usually the Donovans, Doyles
(continues on next page)

5260463/5254806/5275115.title: Béaloideas - Cluichí
5260463/5254806/5275115.text:
(continued from previous page)
They way to play "hide and seek" is that one party would go in hide and the nest would have to seek and catch them. There is a rhyme attached to it. Hide and go seekAll the weekSheeps head on Sunday A half a crown to Mr BrowneTo pay the rent on Monday. Tugga War: Two would join together and say:- Dan, Dan, thread the needlle,Dan Dane sew,Everyone to pass byExcept the very last one.



The tinkers go around from house to house begging for
(continues on next page)

5260463/5255016/5275893.title: Féilí na Bliana
5260463/5255016/5275893.text:
The tinkers do not come to this place very often but when they do come they stay for about a fortnight. Some of them have large caravans in which they sleep and cook their meals while others ask for lodgings for the night. The most of them come selling little articles such as holy pictures, combs, jugs, carpets, cups and saucers and such small articles. They carry the articles in a wicker basket which they carry upon their arm. When they come to the house they
(continues on next page)

5260463/5255073/5276004.title: Fox's Tongue
5260463/5255073/5276004.text:
Foxes tongue - This a cure for taking out a thorn. Ferrets leavings is a cure fo chin cough.



Many travelling people travel around this parish. There names are Delaney's, Furies, Doyles and Caseys, Carthy's. Some of these people are very poor and travel around in small carts. Others are not very poor and travel around in caravans. These are very big cars and are drawn by two horses. They also can shop in these caravans and make fires in them. They go around from place to place and beg alms and food from the people. They also carry bags in the cars to make a camp. They make a
(continues on next page)

5260406/5247259/5276530.title: Travelling Folk
5260406/5247259/5276530.text:
Tinkers are very poor people without any houses.  They camp on the sides of roads.  Some people give them barns to sleep in.  They go around asking food from the people.  The names which are very old.  Corcans, Greens and the Wards.Gipseys come round some of them sell things and the people buy from them
(continues on next page)

5260406/5247424/5276657.title: Travelling Folk
5260406/5247424/5276657.text:
Travelling Folk are to be seen at fairs and markets. I know a man named Pat Ward who sells tins and mends broken kettles and cans.Travellers usually go to fairs such as Ballinasloe, Ballygar, and Mount Bellow. I know two women that come around begging pennies and their names are Biddy Hatters and Lizzy Flynn. Travellers line in tents or caravans. They stay beside a wood so they get wood for fires.Some of them live in families
(continues on next page)

5260406/5247475/5276852.title: Travelling Folk
5260406/5247475/5276852.text: Most of the travelling folk come to our district such as the tinkers and gipsies.  The Mongans, the Greens, the Joyces go around selling tins and other articles.  Some of them sell delph and blessed pictures.

5260406/5247530/5276880.title: Travelling Folk
5260406/5247530/5276880.text:
There are travelling folk to be found all over the whole world.There is a lot of them in the back lanes of Athlone and other towns. Some of those are very poor andhave nothing to live on only the alms of the people and more of them are very rich and  go around in caravans. They always go near a wood where they will have plenty of fuel and twigs which they weave together and make baskets and tables. They also make saucpans and cans and sell rugs and mats and some of them sell delph.
(continues on next page)

5260406/5247564/5276897.title: Travelling Folk
5260406/5247564/5276897.text:
Most of the travelling folk that  come to this district are called gipsies and tinkers. They usually come here on a fair day. They nearly always camp near a wood because they can gather the twigs and branches to make their fires and they can also cut branches from the trees and make little tables which they sell at one shilling. Some of them (sell) travel in caravans but some of the poores people travel in carts and some of them on foot. Some of them carry large baskets in which
(continues on next page)

5260406/5247654/5276931.title: Travelling Folk
5260406/5247654/5276931.text:
6-4-38.Travelling Folk.The travellers that come to our house are tinkers. We bought a can and saucepans and a gallon measure and we gave them money for them. We gave them flour, and a piece of bacon. One tinker man's name I know is Pat Ward from Ballygar. He is not married at all. Another tinkers I know are Biddy Hatters and Lizzie Flynn.The tinkers live in tents or caravans and they stay near a wood
(continues on next page)

5260406/5247695/5276946.title: Travelling Folk
5260406/5247695/5276946.text:
4-4-'38Travelling Folk.There are people travelling about called poor people. There is a man by the name of Pat Ward he sells tins such as cans and saucepans, he sometimes mends kettles or cans for the people.Some of the women sell tables pictures and mats. Some of them have big families and are poorer than those with no families. They camp out in huts made up of sticks and bags, and some of them in caravans. There are others going about the roads known as Lizzie Flynn and Biddy Hatter they go alone. It is said that
(continues on next page)

5260406/5247823/5277007.title: Travelling Folk
5260406/5247823/5277007.text:
Travelling folk are generally to be seen at markets and fairs. Some of those people are very poor and some of them are rich. They make cans, sauce-pans. They also make artificial flowers with coloured paper and candle greace. They carry those round in baskets and carts. They sell delph, pictures, shoe laces, hair pens and many other useful articles. Those also camp up near a wood where they have plenty of wood.
(continues on next page)

5260406/5247867/5277029.title: Travelling Folk
5260406/5247867/5277029.text:
Travelling folk are generally found at markets and fairs. Some of those people are very poor and some of them are very rich. They make cans and sauce-pans. They also make flowers of papers and candles. They carry those round in baskets and carts. They also sell delph and pictures and boot and shoe laces and hair-pins and many other useful articles.Those also camp up near a wood where they have
(continues on next page)

5260406/5247933/5277066.title: Travelling Folk
5260406/5247933/5277066.text:
6-4-'38Travelling Folk.There are a lot of poor people travelling from houses to house. People give their barns to sleep in. They also get food money, and clothes from the people in the country houses.There is a poor man by the name of Pat Ward he sells tins such as cans and saucepans, he sometimes mends kettles and cans for the people. He lives in a small house in Ballygar.There was also an old
(continues on next page)

5260406/5248028/5277113.title: Travelling Folk
5260406/5248028/5277113.text:
6=4='1938Travelling - FolkTravelling Folk are to be seen at fairs and markets. Some of those are very poor and have nothing to live on only the alms of the people and more of them are rich and go around in caravans and sell things. They always go near a wood where they will have plenty of wood and twigs which they weave - to - gether and make fancy baskets and tables. There is a lot of them in Althlone and Ballinasloe and in other towns. Tinkers make cans and saucpans and sell rugs, mats, and many
(continues on next page)

5260406/5248120/5277143.title: Travelling Folk
5260406/5248120/5277143.text:
Travelling FolkThere are travelling folk found all over the whole world. There is a lot of them in the back lanes of Athlone and other towns Some of those are very poor and have nothing to live on only the alms of the people and more of them are very rich and go around in caravansThe always go near a wood where
